Below is my final YouTube video script:

"Are you tired of feeling hungry all the time? Frustrated with trying to lose weight by eating less and less only to see minimal results. 

What if I told you that you can eat more and still lose weight? Sound too good to be true? 

Keep watching because today we're going to explore the surprising science behind how eating more can actually help you shed those extra pounds.

Hey there. Welcome back to Be Healthy and Thrive. In this video, we're going to talk about why eating more can help you lose weight.

If you're new to our channel, make sure to hit that subscribe button and the notification bell so you don't miss out on any of our latest health and fitness tips. 

And if you like this video, give it a thumbs up and let us know in the comments below.

But before we dive in, I'll have a bonus tip that can take your weight loss efforts to the next level. Keep watching to find out what it is.

First, let's talk about calories. 

When it comes to weight loss, calories are king. 

You need to burn more calories than you consume in order to lose weight.

That's where the concept of calorie deficit comes in. In other words, you need to eat fewer calories than you burn in order to lose weight. 

However, there's a common misconception that you need to eat as little as possible in order to create a calorie deficit.

The truth is, if you restrict your calories too much, your body will go into starvation mode and slow down your metabolism to conserve energy, making it harder to lose weight. 

So how can you create a calorie deficit without starving yourself? 

The answer is to eat more of the right foods, specifically foods that are high in protein, fiber, and water content can help boost your metabolism and help you burn more calorie.

Some examples of these foods include lean proteins. 

This can include chicken, which is loaded with protein and is lower in calories than other protein choices since it is lean and low in fat. 

Fish that is high in omega-3. Fatty acids like salmon, tuna, and trout, can support brain function and are linked to reduced risk of heart disease, stroke, and certain types of cancer.

And finally, legumes. This includes beans, lentils, peas, and chick. Along with whole grains like brown rice and quinoa, they are a nutrient rich food that offers high protein and fiber. 

Also, make sure to include plenty of fruits and vegetables in your diet as these are high in fiber and other important nutrients.

By eating more of the right foods, you can actually boost your metabolism and lose weight more effectively. 

And the best part, you'll feel fuller and more satisfied throughout the. 

So you won't have to rely on willpower to resist unhealthy snacks and treats. 

In addition to eating the right foods, portion control is key.

Eating too much of even the healthiest foods can still lead to weight gain. 

So make sure to keep an eye on your portion sizes and aim for balanced meals that include protein, complex carbs, healthy fats, and lots of veggies. 

Let's see how we can put this all into action by following these steps. 

PLAN AHEAD

Take some time each week to plan out your meals and snacks. 

This will help you make sure you have healthy nutrient dense foods on hand when hunger strikes. 

KEEP HEALTHY SNACKS ON HAND

When you're in a rush or on the go. It's easy to reach for unhealthy snacks like chips or candy. 

Instead, keep healthy snacks like fruit, nuts or veggie sticks on hand for a quick, easy, and nutritious snack.

USE HERBS AND SPICES TO ADD FLAVOR 

Eating healthy doesn't have to be boring. 

Experiment with different herbs and spices to add flavor to your meals without adding extra calories or unhealthy fats. 

CHOOSE LEAN PROTEINS 

When it comes to protein. Choose lean options like chicken, fish, tofu, or legum. These foods are high in protein, but low in unhealthy fats.

FILL UP ON FIBER 

Fiber is key for keeping you feeling full and satisfied, which can help you stick to your calorie goals. 

Aim for plenty of fiber rich foods like fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes.

BE MINDFUL OF PORTION SIZES 

Even healthy foods can add up if you eat too much of them. 

Use smaller plates and bowls to help you control your portion sizes, and aim to fill half your plate with veggies at each meal. 

Remember, making healthy choices is all about balance and finding what works best for your body and lifestyle. 

By incorporating more metabolism, boosting foods into your diet and making healthy choices, you'll be on your way to a healthier, happier you in no time.

So have you been able to guess what our bonus tip is yet?

Don't worry, we'll get to it in just a minute. 

But first, make sure to hit that like button and let us know in the comments below if you've ever tried incorporating these metabolism boosting foods into your diet. 

If you enjoyed this video, make sure to give it a thumbs up and share it with your friends.

And if you wanna see more health and fitness tips, don't forget to subscribe to our channel and hit that notification bell. 

We love hearing from our viewers, so leave a comment and let us know what you'd like to see next. 

Now, here's a bonus tip that can take your weight loss efforts to the next level. 

Drink enough water.

We will make this our last action step.

DRINK PLENTY OF WATER 

Staying hydrated is important for overall health and can help boost your metabolism. 

Aim for at least eight glasses of water a day and try to swap out sugary drinks for water whenever possible. 

Making sure to stay hydrated throughout the day by drinking plenty of water will turbo charge your healthy weight loss journey. 

So there you have it folks. 

Eating more of the right foods. 

Practicing portion control and

staying hydrated can all help you create a calorie deficit and achieve your weight loss goals. 

Thanks for watching everyone. 

If you wanna continue learning about healthy weight loss, check out our next video in this series.

And don't forget to sign up for our free email course on healthy Weight Loss. 

You will find a link below in the comments. 

See you next time."
